title: RUST-511 Require DeserializeOwned in from_bson
body:
RUST-511

This PR updates the trait requirement in `from_bson` to be `DeserializeOwned` instead of `Deserialize<'de>`. Since the function accepts an owned `Bson`, the lifetime constraint wasn't being used, and in fact it was allowing structs that could not be deserialized successfully to be passed to this function and fail at runtime (see #165).

This change is technically breaking, but due to the low probability of this actually affecting user code and its presence basically being a bug, we have decided to make the change. We'll first release it as part of a beta for our next minor version and monitor the community for any instances of breakage.

title: minor: fix new clippy lint on rust 1.45
Fix code snippet in README
body:
The code in the README doesn't work because of the breaking change in 0.8.0. This PR fixes the code so causes less confusion. 

I tested the change by running the code in a small program.

title: Update Cargo.toml
body:
Linked_hash_map is unsound for releases <= 0.5.2. Bumping this to `^0.5.3` 

[Advisory](https://github.com/RustSec/advisory-db/issues/298)

title: RUST-413 Implementing ObjectId spec tests
body:
1. Timestamp already tested.
2. counter overflow tested by creating an objectID with MAX counter and making sure the counter is MAX. Then created another objectID which incremented the counter to MAX + 1 and made sure it is reset to 0. Found a bug in the code. Fixed that.
3. No fork in Rust.

title: RUST-484 Add a test lock and move integration tests
body: This PR adds a test lock because of concurrency issues (multiple tests reading/writing from/to counter in an object and all running on the same thread). To be able to use the same lock in src/oid.rs and the tests in src/tests, the tests module had to be moved to src/tests

title: RUST-475 adding getter for timestamp from ObjectId
body: added a getter for timestamp and a test for the same

title: release 1.0.0
Bump dependencies for hex and md5 crates
body:
- hex -> 0.4.2
- md5 -> 0.7.0

The dependency updates should be innocuous and bring us to the latest version of these crates.

title: minor: update badges
body: This PR fixes the travis badge to point to the correct address and removes the deps.rs badge that seems to be broken.

title: fix: Don't use the type for constants; use std
body:
There were multiple cases where a primitive type was being used as a module, like `f64::NAN`. This was fixed by using the `std` module, like `std::f64::NAN`.

fixes #185

title: bump version to 0.15.0
RUST-390 Implement ordering for Timestamp
RUST-454 Implement error case BSON corpus tests
body:
[RUST-454](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-454)

This PR implements the "decode errors" and "parse errors" sections of the BSON corpus spec tests.

As part of implementing the parse tests, there ended up being far more changes (both in implementation and API) than I would have liked, but I believe they were all necessary. The changes stem from the fact that our current extJSON parser would not fail if extJSON wasn't formatted properly--it would just parse it as a document. The spec's indicate we should actually reject such inputs, which required adding failability to all the extJSON parsing mechanisms (`From<Value> for Bson => TryFrom<Value> for Bson`).

To implement these changes, I started by trying to modify `from_extended_document` to shake the boat as little as possible, but I quickly realized that doing the error checking there would require a ton of boilerplate. I instead opted to leverage `serde` as much as possible by defining models for the various extJSON representations of things, while still leaving `from_extended_document` around so as to not break the `serde` implementation.

From an API perspective, I needed a new error type for extJSON parsing errors. To that end, I added an `extjson` and `extjson::de` module to house that type. In the future, I think we could add further generic functions for extJSON deserialization/serialization in there too.

title: RUST-457 Fix Display implementation for Binary type
RUST-447 Standardize API with other serde libraries
body: This PR updates the bson API language to use "serialize" and "deserialize" in place of "encode" and "decode" respectively.

title: RUST-453 bson-rust is missing binary subtype 6
body:
bson-rust is missing the new binary subtype 6. This adds support for recognizing BSON with the new subtype. The BSON library is not responsible for encryption so there is not a need for more support.

Ran
cargo test
bash .evergreen/check-clippy.sh
bash .evergreen/check-rustfmt.sh

title: RUST-445 Round trip decimal128 values
body:
[RUST-445](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-455)

This PR adds basic support for the BSON decimal128 type outside of the `"decimal128"` feature flag. It exposes the `Decimal128` struct but with no functionality, so it can only be created by deserializing existing documents (e.g. from the DB).

title: RUST-438 Add more detailed documentation examples
body:
[RUST-438](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-438)

This PR updates the library documentation for the `bson` crate. It is heavily influenced by [the library docs for `serde_json`](https://docs.rs/serde_json/1.0.53/serde_json/).

title: RUST-429 Move encode_document/decode_document to Document namespace
Various error improvements
body:
[RUST-430](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-430) / [RUST-437](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-437) / [RUST-443](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-443) / [RUST-444](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-444) / [RUST-312](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-312)

This PR makes a number of improvements to the errors in the BSON library. It also fixes a bug where the serde `deny_unknown_fields` attribute was being ignored.

title: RUST-427 Drop decode_document_utf8_lossy
RUST-217 Rephrase unsupported/corrupt BSON messages
body:
[RUST-217](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-217)

This PR adds the key to the error returned when encountering an unsupported/corrupt BSON type.

title: RUST-313 Mark enums as non-exhaustive where appropriate
RUST-410 Rename OrderedDocument to Document
RUST-343 Remove old doc! macro syntax
RUST-346 Implement bson corpus spec tests
RUST-345 Improve naming of Bson and ElementType cases
body:
[RUST-345](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-345)

This PR renames `Bson` and `ElementType` enum cases to be more consistent with each other, with other MongoDB drivers, and with the Rust ecosystem as a whole, in that order of priority.

The names were chosen according to the following guidelines: What other drivers have settled on calling the various types defines the name of the "BSON type". From there, if there is a Rust type (including from popular community libraries) that shares a name with that type, name the case according to that. 

For instance, all drivers refer to what we used to call `Bson::FloatingPoint` as a "Double", which de-facto makes the name of the "BSON type" "Double". Since there is no Rust "double" type, we simply name the enum case `Bson::Double`. For regular expression, there is a popular `regex` crate which names the type `Regex`, so we name the case `Bson::Regex`. The same goes for `Bson::I32` and `Bson::I64`.

Changes to `Bson`:
- `FloatingPoint` -> `Double`
- `Utf8String` -> `String`
- `Boolean` -> `Bool`
- `TimeStamp` -> `Timestamp` (timestamp is rarely if ever camelCased)
- `UtcDatetime` -> `DateTime` (`chrono::DateTime` uses camelCase)

In the next step, I made sure each `ElementType` case shared the same name with its' corresponding `Bson` case:
- `FloatingPoint` -> `Double`
- `Utf8String` -> `String`
- `Boolean` -> `Bool`
- `UtcDatetime` -> `DateTime`
- `NullValue` -> `Null`
- `RegularExpression` -> `Regex`
- `Integer32Bit` -> `I32`
- `TimeStamp` -> `Timestamp`
- `Integer64Bit` -> `I64`
- `Decimal128Bit` -> `Decimal128`

One thing to note is that I did not rename `ElementType::EmbeddedDocument`, since a top level document by definition does not have an element type, since it isn't an element. Let me know if this should just be `Document` to reduce confusion.

title: Remove dependency on time crate
Cleanup deps
body:
- Remove unused dependencies (libc, md5)
- Replace the time crate with std equivalent
- Replace the byteorder crate with the std's `{to,from}_{le,be}_bytes` functions on integers
- Some formatting
